Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project involves acquiring a scanning electron microscope (SEM) instrument to support research and education in science and engineering areas at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth. This SEM instrument is being used by many researchers in various departments, including bioengineering, civil engineering, mechanical engineering, and chemistry. This instrument advances various research projects that involve surface analyses of diverse materials, including natural products, inorganic complexes, coordination polymers, nanomaterials, and other materials. The instrument also greatly impacts the education of undergraduate students with diverse backgrounds, since the institution serves a large number of underrepresented minority students. The SEM instrument also allows students the opportunity to use modern equipment and gain research skills that would be valuable for future careers in STEM fields.

The acquired SEM instrument increases the research capabilities of the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth. This instrument benefits a number of research projects that involve characterizing surface degradation in biodegradable polymers, coated fibers, electrospun composites and fracture surfaces of various metals, solids and molecules for carbon dioxide capture and activation. The instrument also is being used to structurally characterize biologically relevant materials, including bone fractures, nanomaterials, and particles for delivery of pharmaceutical related compounds. The acquisition of this SEM instrument contributes significantly to ongoing research projects and enables the institution to compete for future grant opportunities. Additionally, the instrument also provides valuable training opportunities to both graduate and undergraduate students. This award is funded by the Office of Assistant Director of Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI project has upgraded the materials characterization capability at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth (UMD) through the purchase and installation of a field effect scanning electron microscope (FESEM) from Hitachi (Hitachi SU5000). This instrument supports scientific research in a variety of disciplines across the College of Engineering and College of Arts and Sciences at UMD as well as establishing a core facility for collaborations with small industries in the local South coast area.

The microscope benefits ongoing and future multidisciplinary projects at UMass Dartmouth including:

  1. Novel organic peptide-based nanostructures synthesized by vapor deposition and interaction of human stem cells with nanostructures
  2. Synthesis of novel photonic nanomaterials
  3. Mechanics of composite nanomaterials containing carbon nanotubes
  4. Electrospun fibers for drug delivery
  5. Generation of covalent metal-organic networks for new 2D materials with interesting opto-electronic properties.
  6. Gold nanorods for energy applications
  7. Gold and silver nanoparticles for environmental monitoring

The microscope has also contributed to learning experience and development of characterization skills of the students enrolled in the graduate programs at UMass Dartmouth (Biomedical engineering and biotechnology (BMEBT) program, Engineering and applied sciences (EAS) and other individual graduate programs in the college of arts and sciences). The knowledge of the working and practical applications of the secondary electron microscope is now a part of the core courses in the BMEBT Masters and PhD curriculum and the students learn about the principles of the electron microscopy as well as received hands-on training on the Hitachi SU5000. Undergraduate students in the Bioengineering, Mechanical and Electrical engineering departments working on their capstone projects, utilize the SEM for the characterization of a wide variety of samples such as the lotus leaf stamped in polymers, electrospun polymeric nanofibers as well as various composite materials. 

Training of sixteen graduate students in the Biomedical engineering and biotechnology (BMEBT), engineering and applied sciences (EAS) program as well as thirty undergraduate students in various engineering departments and chemistry department was accomplished over the past two academic years. Eleven (11) peer-reviewed publications have been published, ten (10) conference presentations and six (6) dissertations/thesis have been presented using the images obtained using the FESEM till date.

The electron microscopy facility further enables the University?s participation in collaborative research, and real-time analysis of various materials. It provides the researchers at UMass Dartmouth a greater ability to develop research collaborations to work with colleagues at other Universities, or national labs as well as providing a tool for educational activities pertaining to undergraduate teaching, research and training.
